column1: Camiling (Pangasinan: Baley na Camiling; Kapampangan: Balen ning Camiling; Ilocano: Ili ti Camiling; Tagalog: Bayan ng Camiling) is a  1st class municipality of the province of Tarlac in the Philippines. According to the 2015 census
column2: it has a population of 83
column3: 248 people. Camiling is one of the fastest-growing towns of Tarlac when it comes to income and economy. It is also considered as one of the richest when it comes to cultural heritage in the entire province. The town is also dubbed to be the "Old Lady in the Northwestern province of Tarlac" because it is one of the oldest municipality created by the Spanish government under the province of Pangasinan where it previously included the former barrio of Mayantoc
column5: and Santa Ignacia. The municipality also features cultural antiquity such as its churches
column8: the baroque church of Camiling has yet to be restored after 20 years since a fire burned its interior. The inside of the church
column9: one of the only two Spanish churches left in Tarlac
column10: has become a cesspool for human waste
column11: while the facade (front) and buttresses (side supports) have been occupied by business establishments. One buttress has been converted by a business store into a toilet. Heritage advocates and Camiling locals have been campaigning for the restoration of the church after the reports came out in March 2018.Camiling is the major municipality in north-western Tarlac. It is the commercial center of an area composed of about eight towns
column12: and borders the province of Pangasinan. It is the gateway to central and western Pangasinan through the Romulo Highway (formerly Highway 13). It is also known for its famous "Chicharon Camiling" and its green native rice cake called "Nilubyan".

column2: the area used to be lush in tropical rainforest and was used mainly by the local Pangasinense people. When the polity of Caboloan was established in 1406
column3: the area was incorporated as part of the kingdom. It was ruled by a series of native huangs (kings/queens)
column8: and Liyu. Majority of its rulers are unnamed as no document of them were properly recorded. For a short period
column9: an emperor in China became an honorary ruler as well. In 1575
column10: the Chinese pirate Limahong attacked the polity and declared himself as ruler of the Caboloan realms. The kingdom was eventually abolished in 1576
column11: when the Spanish attacked and ransacked the kingdom's capital of Binalatongan (present-day San Carlos
column12: Pangasinan). It was later on incorporated into the Spanish Empire.

column2: the community was a sitio of Paniqui; before and after
column3: Paniqui was also part of Bayambang. The town's name is derived from a tree called kamiring which at that time grew abundantly in the wilderness and subsequently changed to Camiling.

column1: The community was originally a vast area of Cogon growth interposed with thick forestalls areas stretching into the Zambales mountain ranges. A wide river cut through it. The early inhabitants of the place were the Aetas who make a living by gathering fruit from fruit trees
column2: hunting
column3: and fishing. With the coming first of the Pangasinenses and later the Ilocanos from the north
column4: the Aetas who used to roam freely in the wilderness obliged themselves to move into the interior. The new settlers first occupied the swampy land
column5: now known as "Cacamilingan" on the right side of the river. In time
column6: these settlers began moving to the left opposite shore because of more frequent disastrous floods. To this new location
column7: the residents therein built a small church with Saint Michael as the patron saint.

column1: Camiling became a District Commission from 1834 to 1837 founded by Don Francisco Soriano

column5: as the first Gobernadorcillo. Thirty-eight others followed him. Don Jose Sabado

column1: Camiling was a first-class municipality during the 1970s but was reclassified when the Local Government Code went into effect in the early 1990s. It became again a first-class municipality again on November 20

column1: Pangasinense is widely spoken especially on the eastern banks of Camiling river and the northern parts of the town. Camileños of Pangasinense origin are prevalent

column1: Camiling is known for its architectural antiquity seen from the old St. Michael Church but was burned in 1997.

The Old St. Michael the Archangel Parish Church: A historical building built around the 18th century. It was also the oldest religious structure built in the province of Tarlac. The antique edifice also features the ruins of a Spanish style school which is created for sanctification like the St. Michael Parish Church Garden and the St. Michael Meditation Sanctuary. This church is also the largest in the entire province. St. Michael
column2: the Patron saint of Camiling is said to be miraculous. During the War
column3: He was said to have saved many lives of the Filipinos who suffered in the hands of the Japanese. The church serves as the death place of Pedro Pedroche and his men under the hands of Gen.Fransisco Macabulos who granted the independence of the province. The old Roman Catholic Church was also declared by the National Historic Commission as a historic site until it was gutted by fire in 1997. The baroque church has yet to be restored after 20 years since a fire burned its interior. The inside of the church
column4: one of the only two Spanish churches left in Tarlac
column5: has become a cesspool for human waste
column6: while the facade (front) and buttresses (side supports) have been occupied by business establishments. One buttress has been converted by a business store into a toilet. Heritage advocates and Camiling locals have been campaigning for the restoration of the church after the reports came out in March 2018.

column1: The Old Site of Camiling: Also known as the Old Intramuros of Tarlac. This place showcases the combined ruins of the old St. Michael the Archangel Parish Church together with its school extension and convent which was burned in 1997. Inside the ruins

column1: Our Lady of Guadalupe Church: A Parish church that features the Guadalupe title of Blessed Virgin Mary. It is located in Brgy. Malacampa

column1: Mt. Damas is a crag which is one of the favorite destination of hikers and mountain climbers in the province. As part of the Zambales Mountain Range lies a cave which serve as a shelter and hideout of many people and soldiers (guerilla) of Camiling against the Japanese during the war.
Ubod Falls Is a 160-foot waterfalls in Mt. Damas in Papaac. Considered as the highest falls in the entire province of Tarlac. It is located deep in the wilderness of barangay Papaac.
Pias Falls Another falls in Papaac. It has a greater raging water than Ubod falls although it is much smaller compared to Ubod falls.

Camiling's one town one product is the Chicharon or Bagnet by the Ilocanos of Ilocos Sur and the sweet green native cakes called Iniruban or Dirimin of Pangasinan origin. The municipality is also known for other native rice cakes such as Tupig
column2: Pinais

column1: Camiling hosts Iniruban and Chicharon Festival. Held every last week of October
column2: it is coupled by colorful and artistic presentations and street dances by different schools in Camiling. The festival was established in 2000. A street dancing competition is held annually to showcase Camiling's products and cultural heritage.

column1: Camiling has three hospitals and a health center at the Municipal Hall. The health center serves the poor by giving free medicines and other health service. There are numerous private clinics scattered throughout the town. Hospitals in Camiling are Señor Santo Niħo Tertiary Hospital at Poblacion
column2: Camiling District Hospital at Malacampa
column3: and Salvador General Hospital at Palimbo.
